title: Domain 3.3: Given a scenario, select and install storage devices.
content:
💽 Hard Drives (HDDs)

🔁 Speeds (RPMs)

  • 5,400 RPM – Older laptops, low power
  • 7,200 RPM – Standard desktop
  • 10,000 RPM – High-performance use
  • 15,000 RPM – Rare, enterprise-level

🧠 Tip: Higher RPM = faster, but also louder and hotter.

📏 Form Factors

2.5-inch – Used in laptops
3.5-inch – Used in desktops

🧠 Tip: Check case/bay compatibility when installing.

⚡ Solid State Drives (SSDs)

🔌 Communication Interfaces

  • SATA: 550 MB/s max, great upgrade option
  • NVMe: Runs over PCIe, extremely fast
  • PCIe: Motherboard interface for NVMe

🧠 Tip: NVMe = top speed; SATA = wider compatibility

🧩 Form Factors

  • M.2: Compact, can be NVMe or SATA
  • mSATA: Older, slower, nearly obsolete

🧠 Tip: M.2 ≠ always NVMe — check the specs.

🔁 Drive Configurations (RAID)

RAID 0 – Striping

Speed boost only, no redundancy. Needs 2+ drives.

🧠 Best for speed-focused tasks — not for critical data.

RAID 1 – Mirroring

Data copied to both drives. No performance gain, very reliable.

🧠 If one drive fails, the system continues to run.

RAID 5 – Striping with Parity

3+ drives. Balanced speed and redundancy. Can survive one failure.

🧠 Popular in small business servers.

RAID 10 (1+0) – Mirror of Stripes

Min 4 drives. Combines speed and redundancy. Survives multiple failures (if paired right).

🧠 Ideal for mission-critical systems.

💾 Removable Storage

Flash Drives

Solid-state. Great for transferring files or creating bootable media.

🧠 Not designed for long-term storage or high write loads.

Memory Cards

  • SD: Cameras, laptops
  • microSD: Phones, tablets
  • CF: High-end cameras

🧠 Different classes (UHS-I, II) indicate speed.

Optical Drives

CD/DVD/Blu-ray. Mostly legacy, but used for media, installs, backups.

🧠 Keywords: discs, burning, ISO = optical media.
